The  proposed  Growth  Recovery  Support  Program  (the  Program) 
comprises two loans in various currencies equivalent to $80 million 
from  the  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF)  resources  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  help  Georgia  mitigate  the  adverse 
impact of the global financial crisis. The Program is a follow-up to 
ADB's Emergency Assistance for Post-Conflict Recovery (EAPCR) 
loan to Georgia, approved in November 2008.

real gross domestic product (GDP) was forecast to grow at 11–12%

consequences of these developments could be very severe.  
 
 
The Government and the monetary and financial sector authorities 
in Georgia have worked closely to address these challenges. When 
the Georgian lari came under pressure in August 2008, and again in 
October  and  November,  the  National  Bank  of  Georgia  (NBG) 
intervened to support the currency. To shore up reserves depleted 
in  defense  of  the  lari  and  to  bolster  lari  depositor  confidence,  the 
Government  and  the  NBG  entered  into  a  $750  million  Stand-By 
Arrangement (SBA) with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). By 
helping  to  rebuild  the  official  foreign  exchange  reserves  and  to

Government's  macroeconomic  policy  objectives  of  accelerating 
recovery  through  fiscal  stimulus,  allowing  exchange  rate  flexibility, 
and safeguarding banking system stability.  
 
A  significant  macroeconomic  stimulus  is  required  to  counter  these 
adverse shocks. However, the very high and increasing use of the 
US dollar in the economy constrains what fiscal or monetary policy 
can  do.  Such  constraints  can  only  be  relaxed  by:  (i)  recourse  to 
external and long-term loans from development partners to finance 
core  public  expenditures  and  augment  foreign  exchange  reserves, 
and (ii) maintenance of some exchange rate stability, to avoid sharp 
fluctuations  in  the  value  of  the  lari.  In  parallel,  the  banking  system 
needs to remain stable for these measures to be effective.

dealing with the crisis, both in terms of assessing the need for, and 
designing,  budget  support  and  infrastructure  and  social  sector

the  severity  of  the  impact  of  the  crisis  on  Georgia  and  the 
continuing uncertainty of capital flows.

anchored  on  the  JNA.  It  will  continue  ADB  support  for  the 
Government to help it meet critical public expenditures and cushion 
the  adverse  revenue  shocks  that  will  probably  persist  throughout 
2009.  The  Program  will  complement 
two  planned  ADB 
infrastructure  projects  (the  Municipal  and  Urban  Infrastructure

Pre-Crisis  Performance.  Georgia  has  implemented  noteworthy  investment  climate  and 
public  financial  management  reforms  before  the  armed  conflict  with  Russia  in  August  2008 
aggravated  the  impact  of  the  global  financial  crisis.  The  reforms,  coupled  with  a  wide  ranging 
privatization  program,  helped  attract  significant  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI)  into  the  country. 
Annual  economic  growth  rates  averaged  10.5%  over  2005–2007,  supported  by  a  surge  in  FDI 
inflows  and  the  resulting  increase  in  demand,  and  reached  12.4%  in  2007.  In  August  2007,  an 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  document  on  Georgia  noted  that  "economic  performance  in 
recent  years  has  been  impressive,  with  the  establishment  of  macroeconomic  stability,  a  dramatic 
fiscal  turnaround,  and  remarkable  improvements  in  governance  and  the  business  environment…"2 
Before the conflict and the exogenous economic shocks, economic growth was forecast to be above 
9% for both 2008 and 2009.3

export markets. As a result, all major components of aggregate demand have contracted. Demand 
and price growth have been hit particularly hard for non-tradables, such as construction, tourism and 
transport, which have constituted the bulk of the Georgian economy in recent years. This in turn has 
slashed  profit  margins  and  increased  unemployment  throughout  the  economy.  The  outlook  for

Potential  Financial  Sector  Stress. The banking system has had to deal with both a sharp 
contraction in dollar liquidity as international funding availability has dried up, and with a general and 
rapid  deterioration  in  borrowers'  creditworthiness.  With  urban  unemployment  increasing  and  profit 
margins rapidly shrinking, the ability of many borrowers to repay loans has been seriously affected. 
About half the bank loans are collateralized by real estate, whose prices are now starting to come 
down (anecdotal estimates point to a 15% reduction since November 2008). The ratio of banks' non-
performing loans has increased rapidly in the past few months, while general refinancing options for 
the banking sector have shrunk. The usual symptoms of liquidity problems can already be observed, 
with  some  banks  increasing  interest  rates  on  their  time  deposits  in  order  to  retain  cash  balances. 
Some banks have had need of foreign exchange liquidity, which presented a challenge to monetary 
and  exchange  rate  policy.  Bank  lending  to  the  private  sector  has  significantly  declined  since 
November  2008.  Eventually,  some  sector  restructuring  may  occur,  as  risks  of  continued  problems 
cannot be ruled out. Figure 2 shows how the crisis has evolved over the last few months, triggered 
by exogenous events and shocks.

B. 

Current Response to Effects of the International Financial Crisis 

10. 
International  Financial  Crisis.  By  the  end  of  October  and  early  November  2008,  the 
effects  of  the  international  liquidity  crisis  started  to  unfold  in  Georgia.  These  impacts  are 
expected to continue adversely affecting the Georgian economy for the next 12–18 months. The 
reversal  of  the  international  carry  trade  in  currencies  since  October  2008  (as  a  direct 
consequence  of  the  global  liquidity  crisis  and  heightened  global  perception  of  risk)  started  to 
exert  strong  funding  pressures  on  the  Georgian  banking  sector  through  exchange  rate 
pressures. There have been large lari deposit withdrawals and a sudden increase in the use of 
the  US  dollar  in  the  economy. 8  Refinancing  options  of  international  syndications  have  now 
become  much  less  available. 9   Together  with  the  declining  demand  for  lari,  this  has  added 
foreign exchange liquidity concerns to the deteriorating loan portfolio quality conditions in banks. 
The resilience of the banking system has declined.  
 
11. 
In response, the NBG and the Financial Supervisory Agency have relaxed liquidity and 
reserve  requirements  and  provided  some  short-term  liquidity  support  to  financial  institutions. 
However, this has its limits and it is now crucial to (i) stimulate the real economy with an overall 
framework of public works that can establish a floor to the decline in economic activity and lari 
demand, and (ii) improve the authorities' capacity to monitor the financial system.  
 
12. 
Current  economic  circumstances  confirm  the  difficult  scenarios  already  built  into  the 
JNA,  and  the  expectation  that  fiscal  difficulties  would  continue  thorough  2009–2011  with 
shortfalls  in  revenue  collection  (when  compared  with  the  pre-conflict  and  pre-international 
financial crisis period). The macroeconomic situation calls for the Government to adopt a very 
clear fiscal stance to reverse the downturn. However, the very high use of the US dollar in the 
economy  limits  what  both  fiscal  and  monetary  policy  can  do  to  address  the  situation.  These 
constraints  can  only  be  relaxed  by  (i)  hard-currency  long-term  loans  from  bilateral  and 
multilateral  partners  to  finance  public  spending  and  provide  additional  foreign  exchange 
reserves to back the NBG's exchange rate policy, (ii) maintenance of a stable exchange rate (at 
least to the extent that sharp fluctuations in the lari value are avoided), and (iii) stability in the 
banking system.

BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

48. 
Together with the parallel budget support being extended in 2009 by the World Bank and 
the European Union, the Program will relax the current constraints on a fiscal policy response to 
the  current  crisis.  The  counterpart  funds  generated  from  the  loans  will  help  the  Government 
meet  critical  budget  public  expenditures  needs  and  to  implement  the  countercyclical  fiscal 
measures  already  included  in  the  2009  budget.  Development  partner  indications  of  project 
finance  support  have  been  substantial  but  these  pledges  often  take  time  to  be  translated  into 
delivery  of  resources.  Flexible  and  timely  financing  under  the  Program  is  essential  to  address 
the  budgetary  needs  of  a  countercyclical  fiscal  policy  and  reduce  the  risks  of  the  economic 
downturn.  

 
The  Program  will  join  initiatives  by  other  development  partners  designed  to  help  the 
49. 
Government prevent the economy from getting locked into a downward, negative growth spiral 
that could affect social and political stability. A protracted economic downturn would also affect 
the  medium-term  growth  potential  of  Georgia’s  economy,  and  could  reverse  the  poverty 
reduction achievements of the last few years.

B. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

50. 
The last two quarters have revealed signs of fragility in the financial sector and resource 
shortfalls  that  may  prevent  fiscal  and  monetary  policies  from  mitigating  the  current  negative 
shocks  to  economic  activity.  These  signs  of  fragility  highlight  the  importance  of  the  multi-year 
plan of physical investments and improvements in safety nets designed during the JNA exercise 
(which covers a 3-year period), funded by the Government and its development partners. The 
JNA is the only feasible framework for a policy response to the crisis. This puts more pressure 
on Government's capacity to lead and coordinate the multi-development-partner effort. Also, the 
narrowness  of  options  for  large-scale  resource  mobilization  frameworks  is  a  natural  source  of 
risk.  
 
The  Government  launched  the  JNA  within  days  of  the  outbreak  of  the  August  2008 
51. 
conflict to ensure that there was a clear strategy for keeping the focus on reforms and to secure 
the necessary resources for remaining on track. At the same time, the Government worked with 
the  several  development  partners  to  ensure  there  was  a  3-year  timeframe  for  the  JNA.  This 
demonstrates  the  Government's  capacity  to  act  quickly  in  the  face  of  major  challenges,  as 
highlighted in the recent review of the JNA:  "the Government has managed the recovery and 
reconstruction effort with skill and determination and the results on the ground have been highly 
encouraging.”  
 
52. 
In parallel, It is key to focus policy efforts on reducing the risk of a loss of confidence in 
the  financial  system.  Such  a  loss  of  confidence,  especially  if  it  unfolded  in  a  disorderly  and 
uncontrolled  manner,  could  add  a  whole  new  dimension  of  disruption  to  the  economy,  and 
hamper the country's development prospects. The monetary and financial sector authorities are 
taking  measures  to  strengthen  their  trouble  shooting,  stress-testing,  pre-emptive  and  remedial 
action capabilities. These are now policy reform priorities in Georgia and the commitment shown 
to improve risk mitigation is reassuring. 
 
53. 
Economic  policy  must  therefore  find  ways  not  only  to  act  countercyclically  (within  the 
limitations  imposed  by  the  widespread  use  of  the  US  dollar  in  the  economy),  but  to  avoid 
banking sector crisis. It is crucial that the liquidity issues in specific banks do not affect overall 
depositor confidence in the system. The covenants in the Loan Agreement are designed to deal 
effectively with these risks, and to complement ongoing technical assistance efforts.

were  funding  it.  A  highly  dollarized,  small  and  open  economy  doesn't  have  an  ample  policy 
space to fully offset major negative shocks to foreign capital-induced domestic spending. It can 
however  target  its  limited  policy  tools  in  the  direction  of  key  social  or  financial  stability 
objectives. Developing countries' financial crises have always led to sharp increases in poverty 
levels, and for significant reversals in gains made by economic growth. 
 

Box A2: Lessons from Emerging Markets 

The relevant problem for economic policy in this sort of macroeconomic episodes is then not merely to find ways to 
act  counter-cyclically  (within  the  limitations  imposed  by  high  dollarization)  in  order  to  absorb  part  of  the  external 
shocks (by trying to expand the fiscal and monetary policy space), but above all to avoid that such macroeconomic 
adjustment  is  exacerbated  by  difficulties  in  the  financial  sector.  In  other  words,  although  the  primary  shocks  can 
impact on the financial sector (in terms of portfolio quality and liquidity risks), it is crucial to avoid that liquidity issues 
in specific banks can at some point become problems of overall insolvency in the banking system.  
 
Historically,  full-fledged  banking  crises  in  emerging  markets  have  imposed  high  fiscal  costs.  To  highlight  the  fiscal 
dimension of these challenges, it must be stated that it wouldn't be a mere issue of a funding gap in the state budget 
resulting  from  lower  revenue  proceeds  and  higher  public  spending.  In  general,  banking  sector  problems  have  the 
potential of affecting monetary institutions in developing countries. In many cases, the recovery of assets previously 
pledged by problematic banks as collateral to central banks is significantly smaller than the value of the loans (plus 
interest) provided in the midst of the crises. On average, the length of a banking crisis is 4.5  years, at a resolution 
cost of 13.6% of GDP.5

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Government’s Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Program aims to raise the welfare of the population 
in Georgia. To achieve this goal, two self-enforcing and strategic objectives have been defined: (i) fast and sustainable 
economic development, and (ii) reduction of poverty. To achieve these strategic objectives, the Government’s priorities 
include  (i)  improvement  in  governance  (including  improvement  in  public  administration  and  reduction  of  corruption), 
(ii) macroeconomic stability, (iii) improvement in the structural and institutional environment (including improvement in 
the  business  and  investment  climate),  (iv)  development  of  human  capital  through  improving  health  conditions,  and 
(v) improving living standards for those below the poverty line and reducing vulnerability levels.  
 
The  current  threats  to  macroeconomic  stability  represent  a  risk  to  the  sustainability  of  progress  along  the  remaining 
reform  priorities  of  the  Government.  Social  instability  and  spillover  effects  to  political  uncertainty  can  jeopardize  past 
growth  and  poverty  reduction  achievements,  as  well  as  past  and  still  ongoing  progress  in  institutional  reforms.  The 
Program  will  help  cushion  the  impact  on  the  expenditure  program  (structure,  levels  and  rhythm)  from  the  negative 
revenue  shocks,  by  ensuring  that:  (i)  incremental  expenditure  needs  arising  from  worse-than-expected  economic 
conditions in mid-2009 are met by the Government without complete withdrawal of cash balances at the National Bank 
Georgia, and (ii) the delivery of the core Government expenditure program for 2009 in accordance with the approved 
budget,  irrespective  of  any  subsequent  revisions  to  take  into  account  potential  shortfalls  in  revenue.  In  the  current 
circumstances,  to  avoid  a  free  fall  in  economic  activity,  the  countercyclical  fiscal  policy  that  the  Program  aims  to 
support is directly in line with the Government’s poverty reduction strategy objectives.  
 
The poverty reduction strategy of the Asian Development Banka (ADB) is based on three pillars: (i) pro-poor economic 
growth,  (ii)  social  development,  and  (iii)  good  governance.  ADB’s  interim  operational  strategy  for  Georgia  (2008–
2009),b  approved  in  January  2008,  focuses  on  (i)  improving  service  delivery  in  municipal  infrastructure  within  the 
evolving decentralization process, (ii) reducing road transportation constraints on economic activity, and (iii) upgrading 
and  developing  energy  infrastructure.  These  priorities  were  identified  based  on  the  following  considerations:  (i) 
alignment with the Government’s development agenda, (ii) selectivity in focusing limited resources on a small number 
of  priority  areas,  and  (iii)  complementarity  with  other  development  partners.  The  interim  operational  strategy  also 
highlights the need for ADB to be responsive to rapid changes in circumstances, and the flexibility of ADB assistance 
modalities—a key advantage for Georgia’s development under its newly established partnership with ADB.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
Using consumption as a welfare indicator and following World Bank methodology for poverty measurement, 23.6% of 
Georgians were found to be poor and 9.3% very poor. The rural population was poorer than the urban: 29.7% versus 
18.3%  for  overall  poverty  and  12.4%  versus  6.7%  in  the  case  of  extreme  poverty.  Poverty  in  Georgia  is  thus 
predominantly  rural—it  makes  59%  of  the  total  poor  and  62%  of  the  extreme  poor.  The  incidence  of  poverty  varies 
considerably across Georgia. The highest incidence is observed in Shida Kartli (59.4%), followed by Kakheti (46.3%), 
and  Mtskheta-Mtianeti  (40.6%).  The  lowest  incidence  of  poverty  is  found  in  Tbilisi  (12.9%),  Samegrelo  (14.4%),  and 
Kvemo-Kartli  (17.3%).  Employment  status  is  strongly  correlated  with  poverty.  Households  headed  by  wage  earners 
experience the lowest rates of overall poverty (12.7%) and extreme poverty (4.4%). Among the employed, households

who is unemployed or out of the labor force face a substantial risk of poverty.

The key elements of Georgia’s social protection system are summarized below. 
 
Targeted  social  assistance.  In  August  2006,  following  18  months  of  intense  institutional  development  and  capacity 
building, the Government of Georgia introduced a targeted social assistance (TSA) system. The system uses a proxy-

Social Transfers. The agency’s database currently contains data on 42% of all households in Georgia.

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
 
The social sectors in Georgia were confronted with a number of structural, institutional, policy, and governance issues 
that needed to be addressed to improve performance and outcomes. Resources spent on social assistance programs 
were  insufficient  to  make  a  real  difference  to  the  extremely  poor.  Moreover,  they  were  thinly  spread  over  too  many 
fragmented  programs,  targeted  mostly  based  on  status,  merits  (veterans  and  other  deserving  citizens),  or  a  social 
category (disabled, orphans, elderly, etc.). Program implementation was weak, the staff were poorly trained and paid, 
the record-keeping practice was outdated, benefit delivery had room for leakage, and monitoring and evaluation barely 
existed.  
 
Even  though  social  transfers  are  not  sufficient  to  move  households  out  of  poverty,  they  play  an  important  role  in 
poverty alleviation (particularly pensions as the largest program). The new Government inherited significant arrears in 
pensions  and  other  social  benefit  payments.  In  the  short  to  medium  term,  major  challenges  facing  the  state  pension 
system are (i) to continue paying pensions on time, (ii) to increase pensions to about 25%–30% of the average wage 
(from a replacement rate of about 20%), and (iii) to improve pension administration. In the long run, Georgia faces a 
challenge  of  developing  an  affordable,  fiscally  sustainable,  diversified  pension  system  that  would  protect  the  elderly 
against poverty and provide for consumption smoothing. Under the new Government’s program, pensions and social 
assistance benefits were significantly increased, all arrears were cleared, and payment of these benefits commenced 
on  a  regular  basis.  In  pensions,  a  strategy  for  long-term  pension  reform  was  adopted,  and  the  corresponding  legal 
framework  was created for an affordable, equitable, and fiscally sustainable protection of the elderly  against poverty. 
Overall, the pension system was simplified and streamlined. 
 
The  health  sector  continues  to  face  significant  challenges.  Health  outcomes  are  stagnant  or  are  worsening.  Early 
childhood mortality and maternal mortality have  yet to show  a positive trend. Noncommunicable diseases are on the 
rise. Out-of-pocket expenditures for treatment are still a major barrier to seeking care. The new Government’s program 
aims to sustain improved health care services. Increased public financing for health care and better targeting of primary 
care to the poor are gradually improving the utilization of health care services.

the  conflict,  (ii)  the  impact  on  the  social  sectors  and  on  directly  and  indirectly  affected

International  Financial  Crisis  Exacerbates  the  Macroeconomic  Adjustment. 
Although triggered initially by the August 2008 conflict, the steep drop in FDI inflows to Georgia 
from  August  2008  onwards  (from  $938  million  in  the  first  half  of  2008  to  $322  million  in  the 
second  half)  is  now  likely  to  continue  due  to  the  global  liquidity  crisis  and  the  effects  on  the 
aggregate demand from the slowdown in both exports and inflow of remittances. The unwinding 
of the large macroeconomic imbalance built-in during the last 4-5 years is now in full swing, and 
only  expansionary  fiscal  policies  can  smooth  the  social  consequences  of  this  macroeconomic 
adjustment.  Some  external  adjustment  is  in  itself  unavoidable  as  the  sharp  increase  in  the 
external  current  account  deficit  since  2003  reflected,  to  a  large  extent,  higher  imports  of 
intermediate  goods  related  to  ever-greater  FDI  inflows.  The  current  account  deficit  is  now 
expected  to  decrease,  but  not  as  fast  as  it  could  happen,  as  import  demand  will  now  be 
increasingly financed by official transfers.
